diff_hunk:
@@ -8,28 +8,35 @@
 import sys
 
 
-DEFAULT_FILE_PATTERN = r".*\.[ch](pp)?"
+DEFAULT_FILE_PATTERN = r".*\.c(c|pp)?"
 
 # @@ -start,count +start,count @@
 CHUNK_PATTERN = r"^@@\s+-\d+,\d+\s+\+(\d+)(?:,(\d+))?\s+@@"
 
 
-def run_shell_command(arguments, process_name=None):
+def run_shell_command(arguments, process_name=None, verbose=False):
     """Executes a shell command."""
     assert len(arguments) > 0
     try:
-        output = subprocess.check_output(arguments, stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)
-    except OSError:
-        _, e, _ = sys.exc_info()
+        if verbose:
body:
My opinion on this sort of thing is unless you're sure the information filtering is 100% correct, you're bound to throw out useful information, and so when something breaks (and things always break), the person debugging will be wondering what is going on, and they're not going to be able to see the relevant information from the logs because you hid it.

(Of course, all of this is written under the assumption that clang-tidy's default output is of reasonable verbosity and not, like, debug level verbosity. Which, to be fair, I don't know! I haven't seen it before.)

(Of course, all of this is written under the assumption that clang-tidy's default output is of reasonable verbosity and not, like, debug level verbosity. Which, to be fair, I don't know! I haven't seen it before.)
body_text:
My opinion on this sort of thing is unless you're sure the information filtering is 100% correct, you're bound to throw out useful information, and so when something breaks (and things always break), the person debugging will be wondering what is going on, and they're not going to be able to see the relevant information from the logs because you hid it.
(Of course, all of this is written under the assumption that clang-tidy's default output is of reasonable verbosity and not, like, debug level verbosity. Which, to be fair, I don't know! I haven't seen it before.)
